title: Diabetic Emergency
summary: Managing low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) and high blood sugar (hyperglycemia) emergencies in people with diabetes.

steps.title: Recognize the Emergency
steps.description: Low blood sugar: shaking, sweating, confusion, irritability, hunger, fast heartbeat. High blood sugar: extreme thirst, frequent urination, fruity breath, nausea, confusion. When in doubt, give sugar.

steps.title: For Low Blood Sugar - Give Sugar
steps.description: If conscious, give 15-20 grams fast-acting sugar: 4 glucose tablets, 1/2 cup juice or regular soda, 1 tablespoon honey, or 5-6 hard candies. Do NOT use diet/sugar-free products.

steps.title: Wait and Recheck
steps.description: Wait 15 minutes then recheck blood sugar if meter available. If still low or symptoms persist, give more sugar. Once improving, give protein snack like peanut butter crackers to stabilize.

steps.title: If Unconscious
steps.description: Do NOT give anything by mouth. Turn on side to prevent choking. Call 911 immediately. If available and trained, give glucagon injection. Check for medical ID bracelet for instructions.

steps.title: For High Blood Sugar
steps.description: Encourage water if conscious (no juice or soda). Help them check blood sugar and take insulin if prescribed. Call 911 if vomiting, very confused, or unconscious. This requires hospital treatment.

warnings: Never give insulin unless person directs you - wrong dose can be fatal
Do not give anything by mouth if unconscious
When unsure if high or low blood sugar, give sugar - high blood sugar harms slowly, low kills quickly
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 if person is unconscious or having seizure
Seek immediate help if confused and not improving with treatment
Call 911 for persistent vomiting or signs of diabetic ketoacidosis
preventionTips: Check blood sugar regularly as directed
